abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Arid Lands Resource
            Management Project for Kenya was satisfactory with likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development impact
            and satisfactory performances by both the Bank and the
            Borrower. The components remained the same throughout the
            implementation period, however the drought management
            component was enhanced at the mid term review with the rapid
            response fund at the district level.  The project, through
            its approach to addressing the risk and vulnerability of the
            arid lands populations, achieved its objective of building
            the capacity of communities to better cope with drought.
            Lessons learned include the following.  Risks can be managed
            and the livelihoods of vulnerable, populations living in
            drought prone areas can be improved, through an effective
            drought management system (containing decentralized
            planning, decision making, financing and implementation
            system at district level, supported by a responsive and well
            coordinated national body).  The strengthening of district
            level multi-sectoral institutions can significantly improve
            the effectiveness of project interventions on the ground.
            Capacity building is an important investment and should
            include all key project actors and be carried out on a
            continuous basis. Broader access to social services in the
            arid lands can only be achieved by strengthening communities
            and supporting actors to provide appropriate and
            cost-effective facilities.  Project support of women's
            income generating activity groups should continue and be
            further expanded.
